texts.shortText:
Large, elongate squid with a slender body and triangular side fins that span over half the length of the body and have concave hind margins. The shell is reduced to a slender, transparent ‘pen’ that lies just under the skin on the dorsal surface.

Eye covered by a cornea. The eight short arms each bear two rows of suckers. The two retractable tentacles are elongate and end in a club armed with four rows of large suckers, those of central section (manus) being greatly expanded. The sucker cups are smooth and lack chitinous teeth. Colour ranging from dark red to translucent white when alive.
Mantle length up to 400 mm, maximum weight over 1 kg.

Global: Mainly in South Africa but significant population also found in southern Angola.

Local/Regional: Namibian border to about Port Alfred.

A common species that forms the basis of lucrative trawl and jig fisheries based mostly along the south coast. Forms dense breeding aggregations in summer in shallow sandy bays between about Cape Point and Port Alfred. Sausage-shaped egg strands are deposited communally. Young are then transported westwards by the Agulhas Current and later return eastwards back to their spawning grounds.

Growth rate is rapid, with males growing faster and reaching a much larger terminal size (0.75-1.0 mm per day and reaching 400 mm) than females (0.2-0.3 mm per day and reaching only 240 mm). Live for less than two years, yet some uncertainty remains whether mortality occurs immediately post-spawning.

Predatory, shooting out the elongate tentacles to grasp prey and then tearing this apart with the beak. Feed mostly at night and in the early morning. Diet of smaller individuals consists mostly of euphausiid shrimps while larger individuals take mostly fish. Polychaetes and cephalopods are also taken. Paralarvae feed on small plankton such as copepods.

Forms a vital part of the diets of local groundfish, sharks, rays and the Cape fur seal.

Mating and egg laying take place throughout the year but with peaks in spring and early summer. Squid migrate to shallow (<60 m) spawning grounds during austral summer months in sexually segregated groups. Temperature change is thought to trigger spawning as it occurs synchronously with increased upwelling. Ideal conditions for spawning are westerly winds, no turbidity and sea surface temperatures of 15-17°C.

Once at the spawning grounds, mating rituals involving fighting, guarding and sneaking begin. Large males pair and mate with mature females, while ‘sneaker’ males stealthily mate with paired-up females. Eggs are deposited on both hard and soft substrata mostly in sheltered bays along the South Coast and in large communal beds.

Potential fecundity is 17,000 eggs, and each egg capsule contains an average of 100-150 eggs. Eggs are contained in elongated (sausage-shaped) gelatinous casings, about 2.8 mm long and 2.0 mm wide. Capsules are attached to one another by threads that create large, spiralled clusters adhered to the seafloor. Development generally takes between 50 and 27 days at 12 and 17°C respectively.

Once hatched, planktonic larvae drift toward their nursery areas on the Agulhas Bank to feed and grow. Mature individuals then actively migrate eastwards to spawning grounds in summer.

The most abundant and most numerous of many squid species found in the region and recognised by a combination of body and fin shape and characteristics of the suckers on the arms and tentacles (for guide to local species see Leslie and Lipinski 2018).

The veined/long-finned squid Loligo forbesii has similar stripes to those found on the ventral side of the mantle of male Loligo reynaudii. However, those on L. forbesii are bigger, more abundant and more brightly coloured. 

The Indian Ocean squid Loligo duvaucelii (Port Alfred to Mozambique) has shorter fins (less than half the mantle length) and two light-emitting organs on the ink sac in the mantle cavity. 

The diamond squid Thysanoteuthis rhombus is one of the largest squid in South African waters with a body length of 1 m and mass of 20 kg. Diamond-shaped fins cover entire length of the mantle.
